text: ਗਾਵਹਿ ਗੁਣ ਬਰਨ ਚਾਰਿ ਖਟ ਦਰਸਨ ਬ੍ਰਹਮਾਦਿਕ ਸਿਮਰੰਥਿ ਗੁਨਾ ॥

translation.text: The four castes and the six Shaastras sing His Glorious Praises; Brahma and the others contemplate His Virtues.

transliteration.text: gāvah gun baran chār khat darasan brahamādik simaranth gunā .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਗਾਵੈ ਗੁਣ ਸੇਸੁ ਸਹਸ ਜਿਹਬਾ ਰਸ ਆਦਿ ਅੰਤਿ ਲਿਵ ਲਾਗਿ ਧੁਨਾ ॥

translation.text: The thousand-tongued serpent king sings His Praises with delight, remaining lovingly attached to Him.

transliteration.text: gāvai gun sēs sahas jihabā ras ād ant liv lāg dhunā .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਗਾਵੈ ਗੁਣ ਮਹਾਦੇਉ ਬੈਰਾਗੀ ਜਿਨਿ ਧਿਆਨ ਨਿਰੰਤਰਿ ਜਾਣਿਓ ॥

translation.text: Shiva, detached and beyond desire, sings the Glorious Praises of Guru Nanak, who knows the Lord's endless meditation.

transliteration.text: gāvai gun mahādēu bairāgī jin dhiān nirantar jāniō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਕਬਿ ਕਲ ਸੁਜਸੁ ਗਾਵਉ ਗੁਰ ਨਾਨਕ ਰਾਜੁ ਜੋਗੁ ਜਿਨਿ ਮਾਣਿਓ ॥੫॥

translation.text: KAL the poet sings the Sublime Praises of Guru Nanak, who enjoys mastery of Raja Yoga. ||5||

transliteration.text: kab kal sujas gāvau gur nānak rāj jōg jin māniō .5.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਰਾਜੁ ਜੋਗੁ ਮਾਣਿਓ ਬਸਿਓ ਨਿਰਵੈਰੁ ਰਿਦੰਤਰਿ ॥

translation.text: He mastered Raja Yoga, and enjoys sovereignty over both worlds; the Lord, beyond hate and revenge, is enshrined within His Heart.

transliteration.text: rāj jōg māniō basiō niravair ridantar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਸ੍ਰਿਸਟਿ ਸਗਲ ਉਧਰੀ ਨਾਮਿ ਲੇ ਤਰਿਓ ਨਿਰੰਤਰਿ ॥

translation.text: The whole world is saved, and carried across, chanting the Naam, the Name of the Lord.

transliteration.text: srisat sagal udharī nām lē tariō nirantar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਸਨਕਾਦਿ ਆਦਿ ਜਨਕਾਦਿ ਜੁਗਹ ਲਗਿ ॥

translation.text: Sanak and Janak and the others sing His Praises, age after age.

transliteration.text: gun gāvah sanakād ād janakād jugah lag .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

text: ਧੰਨਿ ਧੰਨਿ ਗੁਰੁ ਧੰਨਿ ਜਨਮੁ ਸਕਯਥੁ ਭਲੌ ਜਗਿ ॥

translation.text: Blessed, blessed, blessed and fruitful is the sublime birth of the Guru into the world.

transliteration.text: dhann dhann gur dhann janam sakayath bhalau jag .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਪਾਤਾਲ ਪੁਰੀ ਜੈਕਾਰ ਧੁਨਿ ਕਬਿ ਜਨ ਕਲ ਵਖਾਣਿਓ ॥

translation.text: Even in the nether regions, His Victory is celebrated; so says KAL the poet.

transliteration.text: pātāl purī jaikār dhun kab jan kal vakhāniō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਹਰਿ ਨਾਮ ਰਸਿਕ ਨਾਨਕ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਜੁ ਜੋਗੁ ਤੈ ਮਾਣਿਓ ॥੬॥

translation.text: You are blessed with the Nectar of the Lord's Name, O Guru Nanak; You have mastered Raja Yoga, and enjoy sovereignty over both worlds. ||6||

transliteration.text: har nām rasik nānak gur rāj jōg tai māniō .6.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

text: ਸਤਜੁਗਿ ਤੈ ਮਾਣਿਓ ਛਲਿਓ ਬਲਿ ਬਾਵਨ ਭਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: In the Golden Age of Sat Yuga, You were pleased to deceive Baal the king, in the form of a dwarf.

transliteration.text: satajug tai māniō shaliō bal bāvan bhāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

text: ਤ੍ਰੇਤੈ ਤੈ ਮਾਣਿਓ ਰਾਮੁ ਰਘੁਵੰਸੁ ਕਹਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: In the Silver Age of Traytaa Yuga, You were called Raam of the Raghu dynasty.

transliteration.text: trētai tai māniō rām raghuvans kahāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.description:

text: ਦੁਆਪੁਰਿ ਕ੍ਰਿਸਨ ਮੁਰਾਰਿ ਕੰਸੁ ਕਿਰਤਾਰਥੁ ਕੀਓ ॥

translation.text: In the Brass Age of Dwaapur Yuga, You were Krishna; You killed Mur the demon and saved Kans.

transliteration.text: duāpur krisan murār kans kiratārath kīō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਉਗ੍ਰਸੈਣ ਕਉ ਰਾਜੁ ਅਭੈ ਭਗਤਹ ਜਨ ਦੀਓ ॥

translation.text: You blessed Ugrasain with a kingdom, and You blessed Your humble devotees with fearlessness.

transliteration.text: ugrasain kau rāj abhai bhagatah jan dīō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਕਲਿਜੁਗਿ ਪ੍ਰਮਾਣੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਗੁਰੁ ਅੰਗਦੁ ਅਮਰੁ ਕਹਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: In the Iron Age, the Dark Age of Kali Yuga, You are known and accepted as Guru Nanak, Guru Angad and Guru Amar Das.

transliteration.text: kalijug pramān nānak gur angad amar kahāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਸ੍ਰੀ ਗੁਰੂ ਰਾਜੁ ਅਬਿਚਲੁ ਅਟਲੁ ਆਦਿ ਪੁਰਖਿ ਫੁਰਮਾਇਓ ॥੭॥

translation.text: The sovereign rule of the Great Guru is unchanging and permanent, according the Command of the Primal Lord God. ||7||

transliteration.text: srī gurū rāj abichal atal ād purakh phuramāiō .7.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵੈ ਰਵਿਦਾਸੁ ਭਗਤੁ ਜੈਦੇਵ ਤ੍ਰਿਲੋਚਨ ॥

translation.text: His Glorious Praises are sung by the devotees Ravi Daas, Jai Dayv and Trilochan.

transliteration.text: gun gāvai ravidās bhagat jaidēv trilōchan .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.description:

text: ਨਾਮਾ ਭਗਤੁ ਕਬੀਰੁ ਸਦਾ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਸਮ ਲੋਚਨ ॥

translation.text: The devotees Naam Dayv and Kabeer praise Him continually, knowing Him to be even-eyed.

transliteration.text: nāmā bhagat kabīr sadā gāvah sam lōchan .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਭਗਤੁ ਬੇਣਿ ਗੁਣ ਰਵੈ ਸਹਜਿ ਆਤਮ ਰੰਗੁ ਮਾਣੈ ॥

translation.text: The devotee Baynee sings His Praises; He intuitively enjoys the ecstasy of the soul.

transliteration.text: bhagat bēn gun ravai sahaj ātam rang mānai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.description:

text: ਜੋਗ ਧਿਆਨਿ ਗੁਰ ਗਿਆਨਿ ਬਿਨਾ ਪ੍ਰਭ ਅਵਰੁ ਨ ਜਾਣੈ ॥

translation.text: He is the Master of Yoga and meditation, and the spiritual wisdom of the Guru; He knows none other except God.

transliteration.text: jōg dhiān gur giān binā prabh avar n jānai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਸੁਖਦੇਉ ਪਰੀਖ੍ਯਤੁ ਗੁਣ ਰਵੈ ਗੋਤਮ ਰਿਖਿ ਜਸੁ ਗਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: Sukh Dayv and Preekhyat sing His Praises, and Gautam the rishi sings His Praise.

transliteration.text: sukhadēu parīkhyat gun ravai gōtam rikh jas gāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਕਬਿ ਕਲ ਸੁਜਸੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਗੁਰ ਨਿਤ ਨਵਤਨੁ ਜਗਿ ਛਾਇਓ ॥੮॥

translation.text: Says KAL the poet, the ever-fresh praises of Guru Nanak are spread throughout the world. ||8||

transliteration.text: kab kal sujas nānak gur nit navatan jag shāiō .8.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਪਾਯਾਲਿ ਭਗਤ ਨਾਗਾਦਿ ਭੁਯੰਗਮ ॥

translation.text: In the nether worlds, His Praises are sung by the devotees like Shaysh-naag in serpent form.

transliteration.text: gun gāvah pāyāl bhagat nāgād bhuyangam .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਮਹਾਦੇਉ ਗੁਣ ਰਵੈ ਸਦਾ ਜੋਗੀ ਜਤਿ ਜੰਗਮ ॥

translation.text: Shiva, the Yogis and the wandering hermits sing His Praises forever.

transliteration.text: mahādēu gun ravai sadā jōgī jat jangam .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵੈ ਮੁਨਿ ਬ੍ਯਾਸੁ ਜਿਨਿ ਬੇਦ ਬ੍ਯਾਕਰਣ ਬੀਚਾਰਿਅ ॥

translation.text: Vyaas the silent sage, who studied the Vedas and its grammar, sings His Praise.

transliteration.text: gun gāvai mun byās jin bēd byākaran bīchāri .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਬ੍ਰਹਮਾ ਗੁਣ ਉਚਰੈ ਜਿਨਿ ਹੁਕਮਿ ਸਭ ਸ੍ਰਿਸਟਿ ਸਵਾਰੀਅ ॥

translation.text: His Praises are sung by Brahma, who created the entire universe by God's Command.

transliteration.text: brahamā gun ucharai jin hukam sabh srisat savārī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

text: ਬ੍ਰਹਮੰਡ ਖੰਡ ਪੂਰਨ ਬ੍ਰਹਮੁ ਗੁਣ ਨਿਰਗੁਣ ਸਮ ਜਾਣਿਓ ॥

translation.text: God fills the galaxies and realms of the universe; He is known to be the same, manifest and unmanifest.

transliteration.text: brahamand khand pūran braham gun niragun sam jāniō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

text: ਜਪੁ ਕਲ ਸੁਜਸੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਗੁਰ ਸਹਜੁ ਜੋਗੁ ਜਿਨਿ ਮਾਣਿਓ ॥੯॥

translation.text: KAL chants the Sublime Praises of Guru Nanak, who enjoys mastery of Yoga. ||9||

transliteration.text: jap kal sujas nānak gur sahaj jōg jin māniō .9.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

text: ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਨਵ ਨਾਥ ਧੰਨਿ ਗੁਰੁ ਸਾਚਿ ਸਮਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: The nine masters of Yoga sing His Praises; blessed is the Guru, who is merged into the True Lord.

transliteration.text: gun gāvah nav nāth dhann gur sāch samāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਮਾਂਧਾਤਾ ਗੁਣ ਰਵੈ ਜੇਨ ਚਕ੍ਰਵੈ ਕਹਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: Maandhaataa, who called himself ruler of all the world, sings His Praises.

transliteration.text: mānhdhātā gun ravai jēn chakravai kahāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵੈ ਬਲਿ ਰਾਉ ਸਪਤ ਪਾਤਾਲਿ ਬਸੰਤੌ ॥

translation.text: Bal the king, dwelling in the seventh underworld, sings His Praises.

transliteration.text: gun gāvai bal rāu sapat pātāl basantau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਭਰਥਰਿ ਗੁਣ ਉਚਰੈ ਸਦਾ ਗੁਰ ਸੰਗਿ ਰਹੰਤੌ ॥

translation.text: Bhart'har, abiding forever with Gorakh, his guru, sings His Praises.

transliteration.text: bharathar gun ucharai sadā gur sang rahantau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਦੂਰਬਾ ਪਰੂਰਉ ਅੰਗਰੈ ਗੁਰ ਨਾਨਕ ਜਸੁ ਗਾਇਓ ॥

translation.text: Doorbaasaa, King Puro and Angra sing the Praises of Guru Nanak.

transliteration.text: dūrabā parūrau angarai gur nānak jas gāiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਕਬਿ ਕਲ ਸੁਜਸੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਗੁਰ ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਸਹਜਿ ਸਮਾਇਓ ॥੧੦॥

translation.text: Says KAL the poet, the Sublime Praises of Guru Nanak intuitively permeate each and every heart. ||10||

transliteration.text: kab kal sujas nānak gur ghat ghat sahaj samāiō .10.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
